description: Glen Marquez is an analytical scientist at DigiPath Labs, which tests small amounts of marijuana for pesticide use and potency. (Photo by Kathryn Boyd-Batstone | News21)
While waiting for cultivation sites to produce marijuana, Nevada labs conduct tests with coffee, tea and homegrown samples of marijuana. (Photo by Kathryn Boyd-Batstone | News21)

Glen Marquez, an analytical scientist at DigiPath Labs, earned a master’s degree in chemistry from San Diego State University and a bachelor’s degree in cell and molecular biology from San Francisco State University. (Photo by Kathryn Boyd-Batstone | News21)
DigiPath plans to test marijuana for potency, solvents, pesticides, mold, heavy metals, biological toxins and microbial contaminants. (Photo by Kathryn Boyd-Batstone | News21)

Marijuana testing is expected to generate nearly $1 billion in revenue by 2020, according to a report by GreenWave Advisors, an independent research firm focused on the emerging legal marijuana industry. (Photo by Kathryn Boyd-Batstone | News21)
Glen Marquez of DigiPath Labs conducts tests in the company's Las Vegas facility. (Photo by Kathryn Boyd-Batstone | News21)
